title: Rugby World Cup 2019 stadium guide
text:
1 Sapporo Dome

Capacity: 41,410

Completed: 2001

Hosted three 2002 Fifa World Cup games

21 Sep: Australia v Fiji – Pool D

22 Sep: England v Tonga – Pool C

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: Edmund Sumner-VIEW/Alamy Stock Photo

2 Kamaishi Recovery Memorial Stadium

Capacity: 16,334

Completed: 2018

25 Sep: Fiji v Uruguay – Pool D

13 Oct: Namibia v Canada – Pool B

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: Newscom/Alamy Stock Photo

3 Kumagaya Rugby Stadium

Capacity: 25,600

Completed: 1991

24 Sep: Russia v Samoa – Pool A

29 Sep: Georgia v Uruguay – Pool D

9 Oct: Argentina v USA – Pool C

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: Martin Bureau/AFP/Getty Images

4 Tokyo Stadium

Capacity: 49,970

Completed: 2000

20 Sep: Japan v Russia – Pool D

21 Sep: France v Argentina – Pool C

29 Sept: Australia v Wales – Pool D

5 Oct: England v Argentina – Pool C

6 Oct: New Zealand v Namibia – Pool B

19 Oct: Quarter-final 2

20 Oct: Quarter-final 4

1 Nov: Bronze final

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: Brendan Moran/Sportsfile via Getty Images

5 International Stadium Yokohama

Capacity: 72,327

Completed: 1997

Hosted 2002 Fifa World Cup final, following three group matches

21 Sep: New Zealand v South Africa – Pool B

22 Sep: Ireland v Scotland – Pool A

12 Oct: England v France – Pool C

13 Oct: Japan v Scotland – Pool A

26 Oct: Semi-final 1

27 Oct: Semi-final 2

2 Nov: Final

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: Martin Bureau/AFP/Getty Images

6 City of Toyota Stadium

Capacity: 45,000

Completed: 2001

23 Sep: Wales v Georgia – Pool D

28 Sep: South Africa v Namibia – Pool B

5 Oct: Japan v Samoa – Pool A

12 Oct: New Zealand v Italy – Pool B

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: Martin Bureau/AFP/Getty Images

7 Shizuoka Stadium Ecopa

Capacity: 50,889

Completed: 2001

Hosted England v Brazil quarter-final at 2002 Fifa World Cup final, following two group matches

28 Sep: Japan v Ireland – Pool A

4 Oct: South Africa v Italy – Pool B

9 Oct: Scotland v Russia – Pool A

11 Oct: Australia v Georgia – Pool D

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: Martin Bureau/AFP/Getty Images

8 Kobe Misaki Stadium

Capacity: 30,132

Completed: 2001

Hosted Brazil v Belgium in round of 16 at 2002 Fifa World Cup, after two group matches

26 Sep: England v USA – Pool C

30 Sep: Scotland v Samoa – Pool A

3 Oct: Ireland v Russia – Pool A

8 Oct: South Africa v Canada – Pool B

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: Kazuhiro Nogi/AFP/Getty Images

9 Hanazono Rugby Stadium

Capacity: 24,000

Completed: 1929

Hosted Japan v Wales fixtures in 2001 and 2013

22 Sep: Italy v Namibia – Pool B

28 Sep: Argentina v Tonga – Pool C

3 Oct: Georgia v Fiji – Pool D

13 Oct: USA v Tonga – Pool C

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: Kazuhiro Nogi/AFP/Getty Images

10 Oita Stadium

Capacity: 40,000

Completed: 2001

Hosted Sweden v Senegal in round of 16 at 2002 Fifa World Cup, after two group matches

2 Oct: New Zealand v Canada – Pool B

5 Oct: Australia v Uruguay – Pool D

9 Oct: Wales v Fiji – Pool D

19 Oct: Quarter-final 1

20 Oct: Quarter-final 3

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: Martin Bureau/AFP/Getty Images

11 Fukuoka Hakatanomori Stadium

Capacity: 21,562

Completed: 1995

26 Sep: Italy v Canada – Pool B

2 Oct: France v USA – Pool C

12 Oct: Ireland v Samoa – Pool A

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: Toshifumi Kitamura/AFP/Getty Images

12 Kumamoto Stadium

Capacity: 30,228

Completed: 1998

6 Oct: France v Tonga – Pool C

13 Oct: Wales v Uruguay – Pool D
description: All you need to know about the 12 venues hosting matches at the Rugby World Cup from the Sapporo Dome to Kumamoto Stadium
